results.title: The Castle of Adventure
results.creator_credit: Terry Marcel, Edward Francis and TVS Films
results.brief_description: Enid Blyton’s famous adventure story about five children, a sinister castle and a network of spies is brought vividly to life. A young widowed mother, takes her two children and friends to stay at a country cottage during the school holidays. They befriend a young gypsy girl who lives in the nearby woods. Across the valley, stand the dark, brooding remains of a mysterious ruined castle. The five children launch an expedition to discover the castle’s secrets.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Terry Marcel, Edward Francis and TVS Films

results.title: The Castle
results.creator_credit: Rob Sitch, Debra Choate and Working Dog
results.brief_description: How Darryl Kerrigan, average working joe, and his small time suburban lawyer mate, Denis Denuto ended up in the High Court of Australia is the story told in ‘The Castle’. The Kerrigan family live at 3 Highview Crescent, Cooloroo, on the edge of an international airport, in total obscurity. That is until the consortium owning the airport decide to expand and the land surrounding the airport is to be compulsorily acquired from the residents. What the powers-that-be did not count on was the dogged determination of Darryl Kerrigan, greyhound racer, tow-truck driver with a keen eye for a bargain, to whom his house is his family’ home and a very happy one at that. Ordinary family.

results.title: The Castaway cowboy
results.creator_credit: Vincent McEveety, Ron Miller, Winston Hibler and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: Disney family film about a shipwrecked cowboy, Lincoln Costain (James Garner) on a Hawaiian island, and his adventures with widow Henrietta MacAvoy (Vera Miles) and land baron Bryson (Robert Culp). Henrietta has a struggling potato farm and through the aid of Lincoln, the farm is eventually turned into a successful cattle ranch. Bryson, who holds Henrietta’s mortgage, wants her land and is prepared to go to any length to get it. On confronting this predicament Lincoln has to decide whether to stay and fight for Henrietta or return to his home in Texas. Cast includes Eric Shea, Elizabeth Smith, Manu Tupou.

results.title: The Cars that ate Paris. The Plumber [DVD]
results.brief_description: The Plumber: There is an unexpected knock on the door and Jilly (Judy Morris) an anthropologist, opens it to a strange man who says he is the plumber (Ivor Kants). Weir deftly crafts a tense thriller, as the man is not all he seems and Jilly is tormented by the man’s presence and mind games over the next five days as he totally disrupts her life. Her husband, a university doctor (Robert Coleby), seems oblivious to her anguish and just wants the shower fixed. Disturbing and unsettling in mood, set in a high-rise apartment block with large balconies that feel lifeless and unconducive to a happy life, Jilly plots to play the plumber at his own game and foils his plans. Written and directed by Peter Weir. Production company: SAFC/Channel 9/AFC, copyright by Salt Pan Films 1978/2004, produced by Matt Carroll. Also available on VHS [301733]. The Cars that ate Paris: Peter Weir’s directorial feature film debut is an offbeat horror story/fantasy about a small Australian country town called Paris. Giving the term ‘road kill’ a whole new meaning, the townsfolk of Paris make a living out of the victims of road accidents by allowing a crazy psychiatrist to conduct experiments on them. They also prosper from the cars that cause the accidents but death, destruction and mayhem ensue as the cars turn against the town. John Meillon is wonderful as the chipper Town Mayor and Terry Camilleri portrays the disbelief in his character’s predicament very well. Production Company was AFDC and Royce Smeal Film Productions with copyright by Salt Pan Films 1974/2001. Produced by Hal and Jim McElroy and written and directed by Peter Weir. Cast includes: Chris Haywood, Bruce Spence, Kevin Miles, Max Gillies, Melissa Jaffer, Max Phipps. Released on DVD by ScreenSound Australia. Also available on VHS [016312].

results.title: The Celluloid heroes: 1896-1996 Celebrating 100 years of Australian Cinema. - Vol. 1.
results.creator_credit: Robert Francis, Anthony Buckley, Film Australia and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: Episode 1: The Pioneers. 1894-1927. Australians of the 1890’s were among the first to discover the film medium, producing a dynamic band of film-makers with a bold and uncompromising vision. Raymond Longford, Lottie Lyall and Beau Smith fought against incredible odds and produced classics like “The Story of the Kelly Gang”, “Robbery under Arms”, “The Squatters Daughter” and the internationally acclaimed “The Sentimental Bloke.” Episode 2: “O.K. for Sound” 1928-1948. The new technology of talking pictures revolutionised the film industry and created new stars. “In the Wake of the Bounty” introduced Errol Flynn. This was the era of the Dad and Dave films and masterpieces such as Charles Chauvel’s “Forty Thousand Horseman.” Australia’s documentary tradition continued with classics like “Journey of a Nation” and “Kokoda Front Line.” Narrated by Bryan Brown.

results.title: The Caribou hunters
results.creator_credit: Stephen Greenless, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The Cree and Chippewa Indians of northern Manitoba lead a nomadic life as they roam the northern stretches of forest and tundra in search of the caribou that is their main source of food. The camera follows a group of Indian hunters with their dog teams as they move with the herds and at the same time trap the smaller animals of the forest and streams. Their focal point is the Hudson’s Bay Company trading post, where they bring their furs to exchange for the few essentials of their hardy existence. We also see their camp life, and examples of their colorful handicrafts. (Award: Dusseldorf)

results.title: The Cell [DVD] (D)
results.creator_credit: Tarsem Singh, Eric McLeod, Julio Caro, New Line Cinema and Radical Media
results.brief_description: Catherine Deane, a gifted psychotherapist, partakes in a new treatment that takes her inside the minds of catatonic patients, aiming to heal their emotional trauma. Whilst working on a comatose child, Deane is asked to enter into the mind of an unconscious serial killer in order to determine the whereabouts of his latest victim. Once inside Deane finds herself trapped there and a FBI agent is sent in to retrieve her. Much screen time is devoted to the scenarios that unfurl inside the psychopath’s mind - extensive and elaborate settings that feature the murderer, (as adult and child), Deane and the FBI agent interacting in various guises. A psychological thriller, “The Cell” mimics the gory excesses of films such as “Seven” and “Silence of the lambs”, following their patterning of gruesome depictions of (typically female) detestable and sadistic murder. Tarsem Singh’s debut feature is principally a visual feast of stylish extravagance that establishes his penchant for intricate set-ups, heavily reliant on computer generated graphics and blue screen technology to deliver the vision.

results.title: The Cat who drank and used too much
results.creator_credit: Timothy Armstrong, Randall Frederick, Yvonne Parsons and FMS Productions
results.brief_description: Featuring Pat the Cat, this rather clever film produced by the US Alcohol and Drug Foundation focuses on the damage caused by excess drinking and the availability of help and support through the Recovery Center. Pat the Cat starts drinking to excess, tries other substances, ignores his friends’ advice, crashes his car and is finally referred for recovery. Narrated by Julie Harris.

results.title: The Carp = Saran
results.creator_credit: Alexsandar Marks, Vladimir Jutrisa and Zagreb Film
results.brief_description: Animator Aleksandar Marks is a master of several graphical styles. Philosophically, he feels at home in the world of Kafka, Camus, the Bauhaus, Kathe Kollwitz and German expressionism. His favourite topic is the increasing loneliness of human beings in the industrial society. This particular animated film tells the story of a small boy and an older man fishing together by a river. Later the boy catches a huge carp in a sweet shop where the fish proceeds to produce lots of sweets for the boy. Finally the boy floats away pulled along by a balloon. Animated by Alexsandar Marks and Vladimir Jutrisa.

results.title: The Care behind the smile
results.creator_credit: Debby Kingsland, Suzanne Baker, Australia. Dept. of Health, Housing and Community Services and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Dental therapists are badly needed in schools to ensure bad tooth decay does not develop amongst children. The film tells of the Australia-wide dental therapist training scheme, which will provide dental therapists for schools.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Debby Kingsland, Suzanne Baker, Australia. Dept. of Health, Housing and Community Services and Film Australia
